title: Miguel Llera
text:
Miguel Ángel Llera Garzón (born 7 August 1979) is a Spanish <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and former professional player who played as a <a href="centre%20back">centre back</a>. He is an academy manager for English club <a href="Walsall%20F.C.">Walsall</a>.
He played mostly in the lower leagues of his country, appearing in only 12 <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> games with <a href="Gimn%C3%A0stic%20de%20Tarragona">Gimnàstic</a>. He moved to England in 2008 after signing with <a href="Milton%20Keynes%20Dons%20F.C.">Milton Keynes Dons</a>, going on to remain in the country until his retirement and represent a host of clubs, mainly <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday</a> (three years) and <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a> (two).
Playing career.
Spain.
Llera was born in <a href="Castilleja%20de%20la%20Cuesta">Castilleja de la Cuesta</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Seville">Province of Seville</a>. After unsuccessfully emerging through local <a href="Recreativo%20de%20Huelva">Recreativo de Huelva</a>'s youth ranks, he represented several modest clubs until <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">2005–06</a>, when he contributed with 27 games (scoring three times) to <a href="Gimn%C3%A0stic%20de%20Tarragona">Gimnàstic de Tarragona</a>'s return to <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> after a 56-year absence; midway through <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20La%20Liga">the following season</a>, however, he was released from contract after appearing in 12 matches (all starts) for the <a href="Catalonia">Catalans</a> and scoring in defeats against <a href="Real%20Sociedad">Real Sociedad</a> (2–3, away) and <a href="Getafe%20CF">Getafe CF</a> (1–3, home), as "Nàstic" were immediately relegated.
In <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">2007–08</a> Llera continued in <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Segunda División</a>, but also failed to impress at <a href="H%C3%A9rcules%20CF">Hércules CF</a>, playing only 11 games out of a possible 42.
Milton Keynes Dons.
Subsequently, Llera took his game to England, joining <a href="Football%20League%20One">League One</a> side <a href="Milton%20Keynes%20Dons%20F.C.">Milton Keynes Dons</a> in September 2008.
He scored twice during his spell with the Dons, against <a href="Carlisle%20United%20F.C.">Carlisle United</a> and <a href="Brighton%20%26amp%3B%20Hove%20Albion%20F.C.">Brighton & Hove Albion</a>.
Charlton.
After a successful <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Football%20League">season</a>, with a third-place finish straight out of <a href="Football%20League%20Two">Football League Two</a>, albeit without eventual promotion, Llera signed for <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a> on 2 July 2009, after turning down a new contract offer – he became the first Spanish footballer to play for the club.
Llera quickly established himself as a fans' favourite after just four matches, scoring on his debut against <a href="Wycombe%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wycombe Wanderers</a> but also picking up a head injury which led him to wear a helmet for the next fixtures, similar to that of <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a>'s <a href="Petr%20%C4%8Cech">Petr Čech</a>; he scored his first goal for the Addicks on 22 August 2009, in a 2–0 home win against <a href="Walsall%20F.C.">Walsall</a>.
Blackpool.
After leaving Charlton at the end of the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20in%20English%20football">2010–11 season</a>, Llera spent some time training with <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.">Blackpool</a> and joined them on trial, making his debut against <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a> on 19 July 2011. On 2 August, he scored from a <a href="Direct%20free%20kick">free kick</a> against <a href="Lancaster%20City%20F.C.">Lancaster City</a> in a 1–3 defeat, and, two days later, he signed a one-year contract with the option of a further year.
Brentford / S. Wednesday.
On 7 September 2011, Llera transferred to <a href="Brentford%20F.C.">Brentford</a> on a three-month loan deal. On 22 November he moved to <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday</a>, in a loan agreement lasting until January 2012.
On 10 January 2012, Llera was signed on a permanent deal by Wednesday, having been released by Blackpool. On 11 February, in a game against <a href="Exeter%20City%20F.C.">Exeter City</a>, he suffered a head injury in an eventual 1–2 away loss, going on to miss approximately one month of action.
Scunthorpe.
After impressing on trial, on 21 July 2014 Llera was offered a contract by <a href="Oldham%20Athletic%20A.F.C.">Oldham Athletic</a>, which was later withdrawn. He eventually moved to League One's <a href="Scunthorpe%20United%20F.C.">Scunthorpe United</a> late in the month, agreeing to a one-year deal also after a trial period.
Llera made his competitive debut on 9 August 2014, in a 1–3 defeat at <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a>. His first appearance at <a href="Glanford%20Park">Glanford Park</a> took place the following weekend, and he scored a 39th minute <a href="own%20goal">own goal</a> in 0–4 loss to <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a>.
Llera netted his first and only goal for the Iron on 13 December 2014, contributing to a 2–1 home win over <a href="Crewe%20Alexandra%20F.C.">Crewe Alexandra</a>. On 5 May of the following year, it was announced he would not be offered a new contract and was free to leave the club.
Coaching career.
S. Wednesday / Chesterfield.
In July 2014, Llera began coaching the under-14 squad of Sheffield Wednesday. In summer 2015, he started working as a first-team <a href="Scout%20%28sport%29">scout</a>.
In January 2016, Llera launched his own academy, Miguel Llera International Football Academy, occasionally sending young players for trials at Wednesday. In August 2017, he was appointed Professional Development Phase coach at <a href="Chesterfield%20F.C.">Chesterfield</a>.
On 11 January 2019, Llera left the <a href="Proact%20Stadium">Proact Stadium</a> by mutual consent.
Sheffield FC / Hallam University.
Starting in July 2015 and with the duration of one year, Llera was part of the staff at <a href="Sheffield%20F.C.">Sheffield FC</a>, acting as <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">assistant manager</a> as well as being responsible for subjects concerning the academy. In September 2015, he became the club's scholarship football coach and also second and third team manager at <a href="Sheffield%20Hallam%20University%20F.C.">Sheffield Hallam University</a>; in addition, he held the same position at Meadowhead School Academy Trust.
Llera left all of these roles in September 2016.
Walsall.
A qualified <a href="personal%20trainer">personal trainer</a> who owned a <a href="master%27s%20degree">master's degree</a> in <a href="sport%20psychology">sport psychology</a> and coaching, Llera subsequently worked as a primary and secondary physical education fitness coach. On 12 July 2019, he was hired as academy manager at Walsall.
Honours.
Club.

Sheffield Wednesday
